newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong stocks close down on lower turnover.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks close down on lower turnover.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks closed down on Tuesday, with the upcoming U.S. central bank policy meeting on interest rates providing the reason to take some gains, brokers said.

"The FOMC (Federal Open Market Committee) meeting is just an excuse to take profit," said Peter Lai, associate director at OCBC Securities. "U.S. inflation is under control and we won't see a rise in rates."
The Hang Seng Index closed down 122.11 points at 12,815.37, after bouncing off a low of 12,747.91. Turnover declined but remained healthy at HK$5.71 billion, down from Monday's HK$6.54 billion
The U.S. Federal Reserve's policy setting FOMC will meet later on Tuesday but is expected to leave rates unchanged.

Hongkong Bank said it saw U.S. rates rising just 25 basis points by the end of next year, a view on which it bvased its forecast that Hong Kong's economic growth w3ould rebound to 5.2 percent in 1997 from an estimated 4.6 percent this year.
Brokers said as the market's turnover declined, prices were more vulnerable to single large orders and large players.
"There are not a lot of natural buyers around at this time of year," said one broker with a large U.S. house. "And there aren't any shorts either."
The market's near-term direction was likely to be dictated by Wall Street, he added.
Properties came in for selling in the morning, but utilities were the worst performing over the day.
HongKong Telecom slipped HK$0.30 to HK$12.90. China Light lost HK$0.50 to HK$33.50, while Hongkong Electric added HK$0.05 to HK$25.75.
In the property sector, Sun Hung Kai tumbled HK$2.00 to close at HK$91.00 on heavy turnover of HK$357.74 million.
Cheung Kong closed HK$1.25 lower at HK$64.50

Brokers said the odd transactions at Tuesday's open that saw Cheung Kong trade at HK$56.25 were probably human error, with a trader keying in the share price of Cheung Kong associate Hutchison, which ended the day at HK$56.25.
The stock exchange said it is investigating the "suspected erroneous" transactions amd changed Cheung Kong's day low to HK$60.00
Most heavily traded HSBC Holdings lost HK$1.50 to HK$155.00.
The China Enterprise Index managed to hold onto good gains following a loss on Monday, rising 0.72 percent to 896.79. Qingling Motors led the sector with a gain of HK$0.20 to HK$3.825.
